repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Hello, this is my first PR.
Close #19708.

`v:event` contains the top-left, bot-right corner of selection as byte-index.
Added `visual_change` ui event that has `[mode, active_selection, byte_range, char_range]`.

Also, the `'<` `'>` registers could be updated in real time and not just when visual mode ends. The code change is simple, just replace `last_visualchanged_start` with `curbuf->b_visual.vi_start`.
I initially used `curbuf->b_visual` to store the previous event boundaries but I thought that it might be a breaking change, so I removed it.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
				in Visual mode is changed. Boundaries are
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1096,6 +1096,19 @@ VimResized			After the Vim window was resized, thus 'lines'
 VimResume			After Nvim resumes from |suspend| state.
 							*VimSuspend*
 VimSuspend			Before Nvim enters |suspend| state.
+							*VisualChanged*
+VisualChanged			When the boundaries of the selected region
+				in visual mode is changed. Boundaries are

comment_data.body: Do we really need to swap here? Typically, selection has a direction (active and anchor).

I don't think the direction is relevant because the range remains the same in the end.

I tried to normalize the range by having the start as the top-left corner and the end as bot-right.

In this case, the corners stored in `w_cursor` and `VIsual` are top-right and bot-left. Without the swap, the event will fire when the cursor moves to another corner without actually changing the range.

I think I should document this.

I think VisualChanged should consider both range change and anchor change, otherwise this event is incomplete and the data of v:event is useless. For example, in VSCode, a selection is defined by its starting and ending positions. Additionally, within selections, there is the concept of a primary selection (In Vim's visual block mode, the selection under the current cursor position is referred to as the primary selection).
Added anchor and cursor as byte-index, should the UI event include virtcol or other data?

We have `getregionpos()` now, which is the de facto way to represent a "region". Does it make sense to represent the VisualChanged region info in the same way?

Then this would become a single field (see `getregionpos()` for the expected structure).

```suggestion
				    region
```

And we could also provide `v:event.old_region` so that event handlers can check if the region changed or only the cursor moved.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1116,6 +1116,21 @@ VimResized			After the Vim window was resized, thus 'lines'
 VimResume			After Nvim resumes from |suspend| state.
 							*VimSuspend*
 VimSuspend			Before Nvim enters |suspend| state.
+							*VisualChanged*
+VisualChanged			When Visual selection changes.
+				For `linewise-visual` and `blockwise-visual`
+				the start is the top-left corner and the end
+				is the bot-right corner of the selection.
+				Boundaries are byte-index based.
+				Sets these |v:event| keys:
+				    start_row
+				    start_col
+				    end_row
+				    end_col

comment_regular_data.body:
> `v:event` boundaries are char not byte positions of the selected text. Should `v:event` give byte positions instead, or both?

IMO it should be byte positions, as that requires less calculation and is more useful (can be passed to APIs like `nvim_buf_get_text`). If a plugin wants char positions it can call `charcol()` or `getcharpos()` to convert them itself.
Not sure if this is too much but I also added an UI event that has both byte and char positions and a mode.
Would be superb for vscode-neovim to have this merged!

Agreed, this triggering based on selection a ton easier (I have a thing that creates extmarks for the selection that would really benefit from this). What is the status of this PR and what can we do to get this change ready for merge?
Why add both (UI event + "normal" event)? How much code would be eliminated if we only added one? This should be explained in the PR desc / commit msg.

The autocmd fires only when the range grows or shrinks, whereas the UI event also fires when the cursor or anchor move, so the UI fires more often. My rationale is that the lua autocmd would be used to extract the text inside the range, so it doesn't need to fire when the cursor moves with the range staying the same.
By combining them, only the code for populating v:event and UI object get merged. If code length is a problem then I think eliminating v:event and the UI object should reduce the size by a lot.

> whereas the UI event also fires when the cursor or anchor move, so the UI fires more often. 

Can we change VisualChanged to work like that? Handlers can skip processing cursor-move by comparing `v:event.region` to `v:event.old_region`. Or maybe we also need `CursorMovedV` event?

> I think eliminating v:event and the UI object should reduce the [code] size by a lot.

That sounds attractive. We can always add a UI event later if it is proven necessary.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(event): add VisualChanged autocmd, visual_change ui event
